Award.AwardTitle: Nonlocal Electrodynamics Effect and Microscopic Intrinsic Parameters in Pippard Superconductors. Experimental Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
Superconductivity is one of the most striking phenomena of consequence for scientific understanding and applications. Discovered nearly one hundred years ago, it took scientists more than four decades to achieve a general understanding of this phenomenon. Soon after, practical applications of superconductivity began emerging. Probably, the most well-known of those is Magnetic Resonance Imaging. Since 1986 physicists have faced a new challenge, the discovery of unconventional superconductors, which defied conventional understanding. The basic concept of superconductivity theory is the formation of Cooper pairs, ?quasiparticles? consisting of two-electrons that transport current without resistance (a supercurrent). The dimension of a Cooper pair is of the order of a thousand atomic sizes and a pair?s mass is about 2.5 times that of an electron. Knowledge of these parameters is important both for the theory and for practical applications. Surprisingly enough, experimental values of these key characteristics have not yet been experimentally established for any superconductor. This individual investigator award supports a project which goal is to measure the size and the mass of the Cooper pairs in conventional superconductors. The experiments will be performed using the most advanced nuclear techniques of condensed matter physics. Direct involvement of community college students constitutes a major educational merit of this project.

****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
The principal microscopic intrinsic parameters of superconductors, important for both superconductivity theory and for practical applications, are the London penetration depth at zero temperature and the Pippard coherence length. To date the experimental values of these parameters have not been established for any superconductor. This individual investigator award supports a project to directly measure the London penetration depth and the Pippard coherence length in classical Pippard (extreme Type-I) superconductors, specifically in Al, In and Sn. Taking into account that the Pippard coherence length represents the size of the Cooper pairs and the London penetration depth is associated with the mass of the quasiparticles, the project is targeted at obtaining experimental values of these key characteristics of the Cooper pairs for the indicated materials. Values of the microscopic intrinsic parameters will be obtained from the profile of the magnetic field penetrating into the superconductors in the Meissner state. The magnetic field profiles will be measured using polarized neutron reflectometry, low-energy muon spin rotation spectroscopy and beta-detected NMR techniques. Direct involvement of community college students constitutes a major educational merit of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Superconductivity is an amazing   phenomenon with an immense potential for applications. Being discovered already more than a century ago it unchangeably leads the “hotlist” of researches in condensed matter physics, resulted in an impressive list of achievements topped by 10 Nobel Prizes. However, there are still lots of challenging problems related, in particular, to the most fundamental properties of superconducting materials. All superconductors are characterized by a short list (only four!) of intrinsic parameters, two of which are macroscopic and two others are microscopic. The latter are associated with parameters of as called Cooper pairs (their size, mass and density), a special kind of quasiparticles formed by two electrons, which may carry electricity without experiencing resistance.  The very these parameters plus an extrinsic parameter associated with purity of material, govern all specific properties of superconductors, which are used or can be used in applications. On this reason knowledge or ability of quantitative measurement of the intrinsic parameters is a matter of fundamental importance for both science and technology.  However until very recently there was no a single superconductor for which the full set of the intrinsic parameters is known.   To measure the microscopic parameters of classical, as called nonlocal superconductors was the goal of the reported project.  This goal was successfully fufilled for two materials, indium and tin, with use of the most advanced techniques, namely Polarized neutron reflectometry and Low-energy muon spin rotation spectroscopy.  Interesting and highly instructive that the newfound values of the microscopic parameters (in particular, the size of the Cooper pairs) allowed us to resolve most long standing superconductivity problem, a problem of as called intermediate superconducting state, at which a superconductor loses its resistance not at once but gradually, simultaneously exhibiting very unusual magnetic properties. This problem was under intense discussion of uncountable number of researchers involving five Nobel-prize winners starting from the 1930s. Importantly that a new theoretical model of the intermediate state developed in our project not only answered the questions related to this state, but also sheds new light in understanding of properties of other superconducting materials, mapping new lines of thinking and researching in the field of superconductivity.

The project was performed in Tulsa Community College in collaboration with colleagues from universities and research institutions of the US, Canada, Belgium, Germany, Israel, Switzerland and the UK. 25 TCC students have been involved in this project. The TCC students took a specially developed class "Selected topics in physics" where they gave presentations and discussed foremost topics of modern physics staying beyond the standard curriculum of college physics classes. 16 of these students took part in the beam experiments in Paul Scherrer Institute (the only in the world Low-energy muon facility) and in Chalk River Laboratory (reactor based neutron facility). Most of the students (20 out of 25) coauthored in presentations at Oklahoma Research Day Conference. 11 students took part at the APS March meetings. All students either already graduated universities (one became professor of mathematics in TCC) or continue their education in STEAM disciplines.
